Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 04:59PM freeariesonline wrote: Thanks for the info everyone.  I really appreciate it.  Not sure if I can make it, but it really sounds interesting.  Again, thanks.
Posts.Title: know anything more about the lbbc. org conference freeariesonline waterlily

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 10:39AM freeariesonline wrote: Hi, mimi, my name is robin.   I feel for you.  I also was recently diagnosed with mestatic bone cancer but my original dx was in 2005.  For some reason the Tamoxifin didn't work and even though I was Stage 1 and no nodes it still got into my blood stream.  The treatment I'm on right now is Femara and a monthly dose of Zometa to strengthen my bones and I receive a shot every couple of months to "kill off" my ovaries.  I am by the way 44, I'll be 45 in April.  The reason for this treatment is that they hope to(and these are my words)starve the cancer to death.  I don't know if your oncologist will take the same route with you.  I'm kind of new to the message boards but I've been a member of this site since 2005.   Its a good place to be for folks like us.  I've been looking and looking on different websites for info and have found quite a bit on this site.   So to everyone else reading this a big HELLO from the buckeye state.
Posts.Title: bone metastisis mimi73 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 01:18AM freeariesonline wrote: Amber, I agree with LuAnn, talk to your doctor about switching from the Taxol to Abraxane.  Same drug only ALOT gentler on your body.  I was on it for a couple months before I became stable.  The worst side effect I had is some neuropathy in my feet and fingers.  Unfortunatly  I did lose my hair but with the summer heat I don't mind that. I wish you luck and I'll keep you in my prayers.
Posts.Title: Progression for me :o( What to do, what to do???? mrs_X_Sunneedazee Barb-FightingBC

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 01:39PM freeariesonline wrote: Dear Lanef, I an so sorry for your loss.  64 is too young with cancer or without.  I lost my mother not to cancer but to diabetes at age 57.  It's never easy no matter what age.  Know that you will always be welcome here and that anytime you need a shoulder to cry on we will be here for you. I will keep you in my prayers and may God watch over you and your family.
Posts.Title: MY MOM IS NOW AN ANGEL...AND I ALREADY MISS HER! LANEF SandyAust

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 11:43AM freeariesonline wrote: I want to thank everyone here.  I haven't given up hope and I am also possibly considering switching back to my old onc.  Or at least calling and seeing if she can give me a second oppinion or another direction to take.  LuAnn, the two women sound very inspiring and I will look up there stories.  As far as a cleansing ritual a friend who is very religious gave me a "cure" that she got from a newsletter  she receives.  It consists of Aloe, Honey and a little bit of homemade whisky.  Your supposed to take 1 tsp after each meal and I must say yes I've been taking it.  My husband is convinced its working and is constantly reminding to take my 'Cure".  I just wish it tasted better!!  Yuck!  But you know something is helping me out.  My coloring isn't what it first was and I do seem to have more energy.  So maybe its not crazy.  All I know is my friend says it's supposed to cleanse the blood. Robin I will look up Dr. Nuttings info.  I certainly can't hurt and maybe I will talk to my old onc about the spheres.  I really don't think I'm going to get anywhere with the onc I have now.  I still plan on going to see this Dr. Bokar at the main campus on the 9th.  After all, the worst he can say is that he can't help me. Went for more blood work today and the Pallative nurse said she would call me with the results.  I'm curious if my billirubben is still as high as it was.  Doc said he might not have those results before Monday so I might have to call then. Well, I guess I'll sign off for now.  Hope everyone's New Years was a good one.  And God Bless You All.
Posts.Title: I don't plan on going down without a fight freeariesonline LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 03:08PM freeariesonline wrote: Hi Sandy,  I asked my doctor the last time I saw him about radiation and the spheres and he said that the cancer was too extensive.  That there were more lesions than good cells.  I don't know.  I know I get angry and think why weren't these things offer earlier when there might have been time?  I sometimes get angry at myself for not staying with my original onc.  I know my husband feels this way.  As far as treatment, I don't have any idea.  The only thing I do know is that most of the testing and that will take place at my local branch of the clinic.  And that the appointment on the 9th may be the only one that I need to make into Cleveland. Thanks for the thoughts and prayers
Posts.Title: I don't plan on going down without a fight freeariesonline LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 11:27AM freeariesonline wrote: Hey Deb,  Sorry to hear about your throat trouble.  I'm on avastin and abraxane and I've had soar throats almost from day one.  I know this sounds weird but its the god's honest truth.  Do they sell CocaCola products in Alaska?  If they do see if they sell their BarQ's Rootbeer in your area.  I swear I discovered this by accident with my first bout of chemo but there is something in the rootbeer that helps calm the mouth soars and soar throats.  I know I mentioned it to my onc and he tells me he remembers someone else telling him that.  Its worth a shot.   Other than that I'd break out the popsicles.  Good luck Robin
Posts.Title: Avastin/Taxol and sore throat AlaskaDeb Roja1955

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 08:05AM freeariesonline wrote: Hi everyone,  I just had my second session of Zometa and everything seems ok, but the first round I too had flu like symtoms and ran a fever for two days.  When I went back this second time I asked the technician if this was normal.  She in turn checked with someone else and was told no this was not a normal reation.  She also told me that if my fever goes above 100.5 to call the clinic and speak with the doctor on call.  Well at least this time nothing happened and I feel fine but I still will be on the watch with future sessions.
Posts.Title: Zometa mthomp2020 freeariesonline

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2008 10:55AM freeariesonline wrote: Maria,  Bone scans are a very easy test.  However, if you mom gets claustraphobia or just can't stand tight spaces I would talk to the doctor about a sedative to help her through the test.  When I had my first one it wasn't bad but I could have easily had a panic attack.  Now I just keep my eyes closed but it still can be rough.  The test lasts about a half hour to forty-five minutes because the machine s-l-o-w-l-y moves down your body from your head to your toes.  But the results are worth it. Good Luck
Posts.Title: Bone scan ophelia jeanne46

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 04:38PM freeariesonline wrote: Susan, This is great news!  I was stable from July till October.  Enjoy your break while you can and keep your chin up.  It'll feel strange for a while and you'll ask "Is there any more?!"  but truely this is great new.  Luanne helped me a lot to sift through the feelings.   STABLE  is definately good.
Posts.Title: Results in- can I celebrate this? SunshineSmiles pinkpig

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 12:29PM freeariesonline wrote: Bonnie I'm kind'a new to the abraxane but I can sympathise.  I've had two rounds so far and it takes me over a week almost two to recover.  I only get the chemo every three weeks so I can just imagine if I were on your schedule.  I probably would not be working at all!  As it is when I get the abraxane and avastin by day3 by feet are starting to hurt and when your on them 8 hrs a day that's hell. Day four is even worse to the point where I can bearly walk.  Not to mention the aches and pains all over my body!  I don't know how long I will be on this.  I go for a ct scan on the 19th to see if there's any change in the liver mets. But for those of you on longer, stronger rounds I agree with the one lady who said talk to your dr and see if you can't take a break.  According to everthing I've read on abraxane the neouropathy disappears  pretty quickly when it's stopped.  I'd also try that B6 thing too. Sorry to ramble on so.

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2008 02:09PM freeariesonline wrote: Katie, When I had my scans and x-rays last year I was told that they could see better on a regular x-ray if there were leisions on the bone than they could on a ct scan.  I believe ct scans are more for internal organs and soft tissues.  Bone scans can locate hot spots but don't tell much about how big they may be.  The regular x-ray will show the leisions and they can then decide if they want to do a biopsy.  Trying to keep track of all these tests and scans can be VERY confussing!!' I hope everything comes out ok.  Keep your chin up!
Posts.Title: CT, bone scan, xrays and progression... katie11 Tracy1964

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 02:00PM freeariesonline wrote: LuAnn, Thank you so much for telling me this.  Like I said I guess I'm just scared.  I guess I had this preconceived notion that I'd be on the chemo until those ugly cancer cells just disappeared but I guess that's kinda silly and I realize that now.  I don't like the idea that this cancer will become a way of life...sometimes active sometimes not...but at least I'm still alive and hopefully will be for quite a few more years.  After all I have to see my son become the next Tiger Woods!!! LOL!!!! I hope your feeling better.
Posts.Title: confused? freeariesonline freeariesonline

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 01:23PM freeariesonline wrote: Ok,  maybe I'm worrying for nothing.  I mean I know STABLE is a good thing.  It means it's not growing, or spreading, however it also means its not shrinking and going away either. But as far as QOL I've had some neuopathy in my feet, some mouth and throat sores, lost my hair, eyebrows and lashes nothing that I would consider unusual for someone on Abraxane.  I still work, still drive a car and I've started taking golf lessons with my 10 year old son! I don't know maybe it all comes down to the fact that I'm scared and I just don't like admitting it.  I mean I'm not one with too much patience when comes to a wait and see situation.  I'm scared and I know I'm not alone.  Maybe I'm just making a mountain out of a mole hill. To those who responded,  Thank you, very much.
Posts.Title: confused? freeariesonline freeariesonline

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 12:13PM freeariesonline wrote: Arc I'm sorry to hear that your both going through all this.  Life isn't fair. I had a co-worker who had breast cancer a number of years ago and her husband was diagnosed with a cancer also.  I'm sorry to say I never found out exactlly what kind but she lost him last year.  But I know that dispite everything they both went through their love was very strong.  And I sure that yours for your husband and his for you as well as your joint love for your daughter will give you the strength to get through these challenges ahead. My prayers go out to you all.  God bless.
Posts.Title: I can't be the only one, can I? Hubby & I both Stage IV arc229 jinan22

Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 02:01PM freeariesonline wrote: I totally agree with Roxanne.  Do what is comfortable for you.  This is the second time for me to lose my hair and frankly I'm more comfortable just going bald.  I tried the scarf thing the first time and just wasn't comfortable not to mention couldn't get the scarf to stay put!  Today I will wear a baseball cap to work for the most part.  My co workers even bought me some of the Breast Cancer Awareness ones to wear but other than work I'm usually bare headed.  For me it's more comfortable.  And to tell you the truth I don't get too many looks.  People will think what they will.  In closing all I can say is YOU have to be comfortable with what you choose.
Posts.Title: HAIR LOSS ozzie2 maggie1984

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 02:51PM freeariesonline wrote: The first infusion of Zometa is always rough.  Fevers, chills...you swear you have the flu.  My trick is to take aleve or tylenol before getting the infusion.  Just we do with babies when they get their shots.  It helps immensely.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2007 06:38AM freeariesonline wrote: I can understand your decision totally. I was diagnosed and had surgery last year. I had an expander implant put in during the surgery but because I'm a heavy set person the plastic surgeon couldn't reach the port to fill it. After chemo I developed an infection and ended up having to remove the implant permanently. I don't think I can stand another surgery! On top of that I'm trying to loose weight and have aready lost 25lbs since the chemo last year. And as any of us know the first place you start to loose is in your chest area! Even if I did have the surgery I'd probably end up lopsided again.
